dt: {bc}happening without intent or through carelessness and often with unfortunate results
{bc}appearing outside its normal geographic range, migration route, or season

pt: {sc}accidental{/sc} {sc}fortuitous{/sc} {sc}casual{/sc} {sc}contingent{/sc} mean not amenable to planning or prediction. {sc}accidental{/sc} stresses chance.

pt.t: any resemblance to actual persons is entirely {it}accidental{/it}

pt: {sc}fortuitous{/sc} so strongly suggests chance that it often connotes entire absence of cause.
{sc}casual{/sc} stresses lack of real or apparent premeditation or intent.
{sc}contingent{/sc} suggests possibility of happening but stresses uncertainty and dependence on other future events for existence or occurrence.

pt.t: the {it}contingent{/it} effects of the proposed law

et: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}accidentel{/it}, borrowed from Late Latin {it}accidentālis{/it}, from Latin {it}accident-, accidens{/it} {et_link|accident|accident} + {it}-ālis{/it} {et_link|-al:1|-al:1}
shortdef: happening without intent or through carelessness and often with unfortunate results
arising from extrinsic causes : incidental, nonessential

dt: {bc}a note foreign to a key indicated by a signature
{bc}a bird found outside its normal geographic range, migration route, or season {bc}{sx|vagrant||}

et: Middle English, borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}accidentālis{/it}, noun derivative of Late Latin {it}accidentālis{/it} {et_link|accidental:1|accidental:1}
shortdef: a note foreign to a key indicated by a signature
a prefixed sign indicating an accidental
